review.title: Encoding the Local Connectivity Patterns of fMRI for Cognitive State Classification
review.abstract: In this work, we propose a novel framework to encode the local connectivity patterns of brain, using Fisher Vectors (FV), Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors (VLAD) and Bag-of-Words (BoW) methods. We first obtain local descriptors, called Mesh Arc Descriptors (MADs) from fMRI data, by forming local meshes around anatomical regions, and estimating their relationship within a neighborhood. Then, we extract a dictionary of relationships, called \textit{brain connectivity dictionary} by fitting a generative Gaussian mixture model (GMM) to a set of MADs, and selecting the codewords at the mean of each component of the mixture. Codewords represent the connectivity patterns among anatomical regions. We also encode MADs by VLAD and BoW methods using the k-Means clustering.

metadata.title: Encoding the Local Connectivity Patterns of fMRI for Cognitive State Classification

sections.text: In this paper, we propose a novel framework for encoding the local connectivity patterns of the brain using Fisher Vectors (FV), Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors (VLAD) and Bag-of-Words (BoW) methods. First, we obtain local descriptors, so-called mesh arc descriptors (MADs), from fMRI data by building local networks around anatomical regions and evaluating their relationship within a neighborhood. Then, we extract a relationship dictionary, the brain connectivity dictionary, by matching a generative Gaussian mixing model (GMM) to a set of MADs and selecting the codewords in the mean of each component of the mix. Codewords represent the connectivity patterns between anatomical regions. We also code MADs through VLAD and BoW methods by identifying the cognitive states of human connectivity models.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: It is a powerful tool that is used for recording the neural activation observed in a wide range of cognitive tasks that are encoded in the brain. Traditional approaches deal with fMRI Blood Oxygenation Level Dependent (BOLD) response of voxels or anatomical regions for cognitive state classification (Haxby et al., 2001; Mitchell et al., 2004). However, recent results show that connectivity between voxels or anatomical regions provides more information about brain activity than the voxel BOLD responses. Furthermore, pairwise correlations between voxel BOLD responses are proposed to represent and classify cognitive tasks. Shirer et al., 2011). Pairwise global connectivity provides better classification performance compared to traditional approaches. Brain connectivity is also reacted by a number of local meshes (Onal al al al al al al al al al al al al al, al., 2011). Pairwise global connectivity provides better classification performance compared to traditional approaches.

sections.heading: 2. Data Representation
sections.text: We use fMRI data from 97 healthy subjects collected for seven cognitive tasks, namely Emotion (Emo), Gambling (Gam), Language Processing (Lan), Motor (Mot), Relational Processing (Rel), Social Processing (Soc) and Working Memory (WM). Number of scans and their duration vary for each task, but they have the same duration for all participants (see Table 1). We use R = 98 regions of automated anatomical labeling (AAL) brain atlas Tzourio-Mazoyer et al. (2002) except those that cover the cerebellum. Each region is represented by ri, where i = 2,.., R. which contains a series of voxels.

sections.heading: 3. Encoding of Mesh Arc Descriptors
sections.text: In this section, we present our framework for encoding MADs. First, we estimate that MADs represent the local connectivity patterns of cognitive tasks. Next, we reduce the dimension of MAD space using Principal Component Analysis (PCA). Then, we adapt GMMs to the set of MADs. Finally, we encode MADs using three methods, using their distance from the centers of GMMs: Fisher Vectors (FV), Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors (VLAD), and Bag of Words (BoW). The encoded MADs are used to train an SVM classifier for cognitive task classification. Fig. 1 outlines the steps of our coding framework.

sections.text: In this study, we form a star network around each ri region by connecting the region to its functionally closest neighboring regions. Functionally, p-closest neighbors of a region are defined by the regions that have the p-largest Pearson correlation coefficient associated with that region during a cognitive task. sections.heading: 3.2. Encoding Methods
sections.text: In this section, we explain how to encode MADs for fMRI data analysis.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Fisher Vector (FV) Encoding
sections.text: Considering a set of vectors, the FV method is a deviation of the distribution of vectors from a dictionary typically described by a diagonal Gaussian mixing model (GMM) (Carvajal et al., 2016). Within the proposed framework, our vectors are MADs obtained from fMRI data. We obtain a brain-connectivity dictionary of MADs by modeling the characteristics using a GMM. To fulfill the assumption of a diagonal covariance matrix of GMM and obtain early uncorrelated characteristics, we apply PCA to MADs. For simplification, we use the same notation for MADs at the output of PCA, so that ai represents the projection of a MAD in a D-dimensional space.Let A = {ai, RD} Ri = 1 denote a set of D-dimensional MADs derived from a single task of a single subject.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors (VLAD)
sections.text: VLAD encodes a set of descriptors into a dictionary, which is calculated by k-mean clustering method. In the proposed framework, we first perform k-mean clustering of MADs on the training data. Therefore, the cluster centroids {µ} Kk = 1 correspond to our code words of the brain connectivity dictionary. Then we associate each MAD ai with its closest code word NN (ai) in the dictionary, so that NN (ai) = argminul-k-ai − µk-2, where "2" is the euclidean norm. Recover from the previous subsection that A = {ai} Ri = 1 represents the set of D-dimensional MADs belonging to a single task of a single subject, each of which is sampled from A containing all MADs belonging to all tasks of all subjects.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Bag-of-Words (BoW)
sections.text: We also code MADs using the BoW approach, where the words correspond to a set of selected MADs. First, we cluster MADs we have obtained from training data using a k-mean cluster method. Then, for each A, we calculate the number of MADs, nAk, that belong to the kth cluster. Finally, we represent each sample by a K-dimensional vector so that NA = [nA1, n A 2,..., n A k].

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Results
sections.text: We will conduct two sets of experiments: First, we will classify the cognitive tasks of HCP datasets by raw and coded MADs to see the effects of coding on MADs, and compare the performance of different coding methods. To investigate the performance of MADs compared to common fMRI representation methods, we will also classify cognitive tasks by average BOLD responses and their Pearson correlations. Finally, we will visualize and analyze the codewords of the proposed brain connectivity dictionary.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion and Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, we propose a novel framework to encode the local connectivity patterns of the fMRI data for classifying the cognitive states of the fMRI task. fMRI connectivity patterns are modelled by an ensemble of local networks formed around each anatomical region. MADs are estimated by using comb regression, assuming a linear relationship between anatomical regions. fMRI connectivity patterns such as FV, VLAD and BoW are used to encode MADs. We also create a brain connectivity conditioner by matching a GMM to the set of all MADs to analyze the connectivity patterns of fMRI data in relation to anatomical regions. We observe that the FV encoding of MADs is more successful than VADD and BoW methods. In addition, FV-analyzing the coding of MADs results in an energy-dependent MADD, which also enhances the coding power of MS.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, we propose a novel framework to encode the local connectivity patterns of brain, using Fisher Vectors (FV), Vector of Locally Aggregated Descriptors (VLAD) and Bag-of-Words (BoW) methods. We first obtain local descriptors, called Mesh Arc Descriptors (MADs) from fMRI data, by forming local meshes around anatomical regions, and estimating their relationship within a neighborhood. Then, we extract a dictionary of relationships, called brain connectivity dictionary by fitting a generative Gaussian mixture model (GMM) to a set of MADs, and selecting the codewords at the mean of each component of the mixture. Codewords represent the connectivity patterns among anatomical regions. We also encode MADs by VLAD and BoW methods using the k-Means clustering. We classify the cognitive states of Human Connectome Project (HCP) task fMRI dataset, where we train support vector machines (SVM) by the encoded MADs. Results demonstrate that, FV encoding of MADs can be successfully employed for classification of cognitive tasks, and outperform the VLAD and BoW representations. Moreover, we identify the significant Gaussians in mixture models by computing energy of their corresponding FV parts, and analyze their effect on classification accuracy. Finally, we suggest a new method to visualize the codewords of brain connectivity dictionary.
